: [junit] ClasspathWalker (even better)


J.B wrote:

>      So you have on=
e set of object-level tests and one set of API-level
tests.

Maybe, but I f=
eel it isn't that simple. As I go up the chain, aggregate
this/that, the de=
pendencies build & it isn't a single layer. Maybe it is
multiple layers.

>=
      I recommend simply running them separately. If you're using Eclipse,
=
place
them in separate projects.
>      You would have three projects:
>
> =
           My Production Code
>            My Object-Level Tests
>         =
   My API-Level Tests

Thanks, but...

First, you stepped into my pet peeve=
 w/ Eclipse. Run the "all tests" on one
project and it runs all the tests o=
n dependent projects. I believe it just
walks the classpath not the project=
 path. It doesn't know the difference.

Second, even if I only had a few la=
yers -- and not a complex hierarchy, I'd
like the chance to do this within =
projects not at that level. Two lowest
level tests might have what I consid=
er a dependency.

>      When an API-level test fails, run the object-level=
 tests to find out
what
object/method in
>      particular failed, then fix=
 the problem.

>      If the API-level tests fail and the object-level test=
s don't fail,
then
you're missing an object-level
>      test, so write it.=


First thing I do when I see a bug is review what tests  I am missing that=

should have caught it. I agree. I just do it at all levels in the stack, n=
ot
at two.

regards

Adam
